column1: <div class="main_content">
How you can influence Health and Social Care Services in Tameside
<ul class="square">
• Having your say
<ul class="square">
• About your own care
• When things go wrong
• Taking a wider view
• Putting your experience to work
• About how services should develop in the future
• Taking control
• Making it easier to have your say
• Will having your say make a difference?
• Who to Contact
• Service User and Carer Forums
• Making a Complaint, Suggestion or Compliment
General queries about user involvement can be made to the User Involvement Team:
<hr title="Horizontal Rule" />
Having your say
The Government and Local Councils want people to be involved in decisions that affect their lives.
Some of these decisions are about Health and Social Care Services.
The Health and Social Care agencies in Tameside want to work in partnership with the people who might use their services, to make these as good as possible.
This page tells you how you can have your say about Health and Social Care services and be involved in making sure that they meet the needs of local people.
About your own care

If you are receiving a service yourself, or caring for some one who is elderly, sick or disabled, you can talk to a Social Worker about what you think would help you best in your situation. The Social Worker will listen to you and take your ideas and wishes into account when organising the support you need.

Alternatively, you may be interested in the Direct Payments scheme, which enables people who are assessed as needing services to make their own care arrangements with money provided by Social Care and Health.
Whether you have services provided or arrange them yourself, our aim is to work in partnership with you to find the best solution to your particular needs.
When things go wrong

We welcome comments about the services we provide. If you are unhappy with the services you receive, please tell us. This gives us an opportunity to put things right. It also helps us to identify how we can improve the service in the longer term. If a lot of people are having the same problem, we need to look at why this keeps happening. You can tell your Social Worker what is wrong or you can contact our Complaints Manager. Of course, if you are happy with the service you receive, we should like to hear about this too.
Taking a wider view

From time to time, we look at sections of Social Care and Health to make sure that they are working properly. For example, we may review Meals on Wheels or Day Centres. When we do this, we try to contact a sample of people who use the service, to find out what they think about it. We do this by sending out questionnaires, or we may organise a group meeting or talk to service users on a one-to-one basis, or on the telephone. You don't have to take part in service reviews, but if you do you will be helping us to identify what is working well and what needs to change. This will benefit everyone who uses the service.

Sometimes, a group of Service Users or Carers meet regularly to keep an eye on how one particular part of the service is developing. An example of this is the monitoring group for the Interpreter Service for Deaf and Hard of Hearing People. The group meets with managers three or four times a year to talk about any problems which have come up.
Putting your experience to work
This input is valuable because it brings Service Users' direct experience of what is needed right into the day-to-day operation of Social Care and Health.
Service Users and Carers can be involved in interviewing and appointing staff and in steering groups which are set up to oversee particular pieces of work.

Some Service Users and Carers have also been involved in training staff. We always try to make sure that they are part of the training team. Training can be provided to Service Users and Carers who want to develop their skills in this area.
About how services should develop in the future

If you are interested in finding out more about how Health and Social Care services are organised, or would like to put forward your views about how they should develop, you may like to come along to one of the Service User/Carer Forums. These bring together Service Users, Carers and managers to look at major policy issues.

The Forums allow managers to tell Service Users and Carers about changes to services or to discuss plans for the future. The Forums also enable Service Users and Carers to discuss among themselves what they think are the most important areas needing attention and to put these views to service managers. The Forums invite a range of guest speakers to talk about Health and Social Care issues. They publish newsletters and occasionally visit other projects to look at new developments in other areas. They are linked to the top level planning committees where senior Health and Social Care and Health mangers meet to discuss strategic plans.
Taking control

There may be times when Service Users or Carers feel that they would like to be involved in the management of a particular service, or even run a service in their own right. An example of this is the Fairway Cooperative Project Ltd. in Denton. This is a scheme that provides work opportunities for people with learning disabilities.

If this high level of involvement seems the right way to provide what is needed and looks as if it would work well, help is available with business planning and management skills from various sections of the Council and from voluntary sector support agencies.
Making it easier to have your say

People can be reluctant to 'have their say' because they worry that if they criticise something, they will get someone into trouble, or be victimised in some way. Please be reassured that this will not happen. We want to provide high quality services and listening to criticism and constructive comment is part of the process of continually improving what we do.
<ul class="square">

• We will try to make sure that you have the information you need in order to put forward your views. This could be information about what services, or level of service you can expect, what your rights are, or how, and by whom, decisions are made.
• We will try to make sure that people who need help to put over their views get this from an independent advocacy agency.
• We can offer training to make you feel more confident about having your say.
• We are also training professionals to treat Service Users and Carers as partners in improving services.
• We will try not to use jargon so it is clear to everyone what we are talking about.

• We will make sure that you are not out of pocket for helping us. For example, if we ask you to come to a meeting, we will refund your travel costs or provide transport if you have special needs. For some meetings we can also provide sitting services if you are looking after someone who needs constant attention, or help with child care.

• We will do our best to respond to any needs you may have resulting from an illness or disability. For instance, we can produce information in large print, Braille or on tape, provide lip speakers, sign language interpreters and loop systems, or arrange for a temporary personal assistant to help people with reduced mobility.
• We will try to provide the right support for people who do not use English as their language of communication and make sure that venues for meetings are accessible.
• We will do our best to reach people who are often excluded from consultation by offering opportunities for them to talk to us in places and ways which they feel comfortable with.
Will having your say make a difference?
People who have worked with us in the past tell us that they enjoy having their say but that there are things that they find frustrating. We are trying to get better at:
<ul class="square">
• Giving people enough time to think about things. We tend to ask for views at short notice.
• Building an ongoing relationship rather than relying on one off events.
• Being clear about what can be changed as a result of what Service Users and Carers say and what can't.
• Feeding what people say into the planning process and reporting back on what happens as a result.
• Making sure that there is evidence of Service User and Carer views in planning documents and decision making.

Of course, there will always be a wide range of opinion among Service Users and Carers and managers. We can't always do what everyone wants and sometimes managers will make decisions that some people disagree with. However, by having your say, you can ensure that decisions are made in the light of the fullest possible information and that services are of a high quality and meet needs as effectively as possible within the resources available.
Who to Contact
For general information about opportunities for user involvement contact the User Involvement Team using the contact details at the bottom of this page.
The User Involvement team can also give information about advocacy services available locally.
Service User and Carer Forums
The Really Important Questions Group
The Development Worker for Older People, Ryecroft Hall, Manchester Road, Audenshaw, Tameside, M34 5GJ
0161 370 1179  0161 370 1183 0161 301 2490
This group brings together people who have an itnerest in Social Care and Health issues.
Tameside Advocacy Project (TAP) and The Mental Health Forum -

Tameside Advocacy Project provides advocacy and user involvement support for users of Mental Health Services in Tameside. There is a Tameside-based development worker. For further information contact:
Tameside Advocacy Project, 68a Welbeck Street South, Ashton-under-Lyne, OL6 7TD
0161 331 9053 0161 308 3633

This organisation supports people with mental health needs to have a voice in the Monitor and Planning of Mental Health Services. The Mental Health Forum links to the Local Implementation Team for Mental Health. TAP also offers advocacy support for individuals dealing with Mental Health Services.
Deaf, Hard of Hearing, Visual Impairment or Physical Disabilities Forums/User Groups
For any of the Forums listed below please contact:-
The User Involvement Development Worker, Service Development and Customer Support Unit, Ryecroft Hall, Manchester Road, Audenshaw, M34 5GJ.
0161 370 1179 0161 370 1183 0161 301 2490
People First Tameside (Learning Disability Advocacy Service)
St Michael's Court, Ashton-under-Lyne
0161 308 3699
People First supports adults with learning disabilities to get their views across to managers of services. It is a self organised group of adults with learning disabilities.
The Carers Forum
The Carers Centre, 50 Warrington Street, Ashton-under-Lyne OL6 7JX
0161 342 3344  0161 342 3720  0161 342 3721  Send a Message to the Carers Centre

If you are caring for a family member or friend who is elderly, ill or disabled, the Carers Centre can give you information about services available to help you and link you to other people with similar responsibilities. The Carers Forum meets regularly to discuss Carers issues. The Carers Council links Carers to the strategic planning process.
Young Carers, under the age of 18, can join the Young Carers Group. For further information contact Young Carers Worker:
Family Support Team Office, Newton, Family Centre, Victoria Street, Newton, Hyde
0161 368 3192 0161 368 3215
Minority Ethnic Communities
Race Equality and Diversity Team, Service Development and Customer Support Unit, Ryecroft Hall, Manchester Road, Audenshaw, M34 5GJ
0161 370 1179 0161 370 1183 0161 301 2490 Send a Message to Race Equality Team

If you are a member of one of Tameside's minority ethnic communities and want to have your say about the services available to you, the Race Equality and Diversity team can support you to get involved in any of the groups mentioned within this page.
Children's Services
User Involvement Coordinator-Children and Families Service, Tameside Social Care and Health, Union Street, Hyde, SK14 1ND
0161 342 4325 0161 368 8642
The user involvement worker in Children's Services coordinates a number of projects to consult with both children receiving services and their families.
Children who are looked after by Tameside Council can also have their say through the Children's Rights Officer. Please contact via the Children's Services User Involvement Coordinator.

Social Care and Health
Tameside Social Care and Health is committed to providing quality services. We need to hear from you if you have any complaints, suggestions or compliments about the service you receive.
